Halifax edge past Vanbrugh to progress

11/06/2013

Halifax firsts booked their place in the Cup semi-finals on Monday after squeezing past a spirited Vanbrugh seconds side

Image by

By undefined undefined

HALIFAX FIRSTS 1-0 VANBRUGH SECONDS Cup Quarter Final
Images: Agatha Torrance Halifax firsts booked their place in the Cup semi-finals on Monday after squeezing past a spirited Vanbrugh seconds side. In a much tighter contest than many had predicted, both sides started brightly, but it was Halifax that had the earlier chances with chances for Dan Jones coming in at the back post. Tom Parish then put in Vanbrugh's first meaningful chance with a good cross which was well held by Fax keeper Jonny Sim. With the ball in the air a lot early on, the first touch proved crucial to retaining possession and some excellent control from Matt Mawdesley paid off for Halifax as he knocked the ball through for Jones to run on to; however, he was unable to convert. Halifax then had a corner, but it was well defended. Callum Woodall and Adam Lewis then combined well for Vanbrugh to create a good chance, resulting in Lewis firing just wide. The game panned out into an end-to-end affair, with Halifax in particular playing a high line but defending well. Hamish Denham then headed straight at Tom Williams, before Vanbrugh had the ball in the back of the net after an excellent shot - but it was chalked off as the whistle had been blown for a foul. Halifax then caused further problems for the Vanbrugh defence; a good run from Mawdesley was quashed by an excellent clearance from James Robinson, then Tom Day lost his man and caused problems for Williams between the sticks. A superb curling effort from Mawdesley outside of the area was then heading for the top corner of the net before an excellent save by Williams. However, Vanbrugh continued to have chances and looked as likely to score the opener as their opponents. Two free kicks from Woodall in dangerous areas threatened the Halifax goal, before Adam Lewis demonstrated some outstanding skill to beat 4 men to work his way into the Fax area. As the game approached half time, both sides looked comfortable on the ball, with hard work from the Vanbrugh midfield resulting in plenty of possession. Nevertheless, neither side was able to break the deadlock before half time. Both upped the tempo in the second half, and Halifax almost went close to going ahead immediately after the restart but were unable to beat Williams. Some excellent build-up play from Vanbrugh then threatened, with chances coming for Parish and John Sanderson. Vanbrugh then found themselves under further pressure from their opponents. A tame shot from Connor McCoy ended up in the arms of Williams, before the shot-stopper then saved again from Mawdesley, leading to two successive corners. Although these set pieces were cleared, a dangerous long-throw from Denham was hurled into the Vanbrugh area. Mawdesley latched onto the end and finally opened the scoring, putting Halifax one goal to the good. Vanbrugh responded brightly despite falling behind, and enjoyed their best football of the game shortly afterwards as some outstanding build-up play allowed Parish to go through one-on-one with Halifax keeper Sim. However, the Vanbrugh front-man was unlucky to blaze his shot narrowly over the bar. After this, Vanbrugh had a spell of dominance as two corners were cleared, before Parish was perhaps harshly judged to have been offside by the referee. Halifax then earned another corner but the header was well off target, then McCoy's shot cleared Williams' near post. Vanbrugh had further opportunities to level the scores as the game reached a conclusion, as Lewis was involved in a collision with Sim before a long-range shot from Sanderson was not too far over. However, despite their efforts, Vanbrugh were unable to find a goal, meaning that Halifax progress through to the semi-finals after a close 1-0 victory. Vanbrugh will be pleased with their efforts, narrowly going down by a single goal against a dangerous Halifax side which look a good prospect as the Cup reaches the latter stages. Halifax, meanwhile will be happy to have avoided an upset, but will need to up their game in their next match if they are to make it through to the final.
